publication.author: Horton, D.; Prain, G. (CIP).; Thiele, G. (CIP).
publication.title: Perspectives on partnership: A literature review
publication.Pub_Abstract: Partnership is now considered an essential way of working in many fields and this literature review represents the first step in CIP's partnership research. The paper surveys contemporary literature useful for understanding and improving the roles of partnership and collaboration in the context of agricultural research for development. Conclusions and insights are grouped together from four distinct literatures: research studies; professional evaluation literature; practitioner-oriented reviews, guidelines and assessment tools; and CGIAR-related reviews, evaluations and policy documents. The paper also highlights gaps in current knowledge.

publication.author: International Potato Center (CIP)
publication.title: La Ruta del Condor.A promising adaptation approach
publication.Pub_Abstract: The Ruta Condor microcenters offer the opportunity to study and save native varieties in their native environment, in situ, where they are exposed to the natural stresses of seasonal variation and climate change

publication.author: International Potato Center (CIP)
publication.title: Agriculture and soil carbon: Playing a major role in the mitigation of climate change
publication.Pub_Abstract: New advances developed jointly by the International Potato Center and the Brazilian Agricultural Research Corporation (EMBRAPA)have made it possible to measure, monitor, and verify soil carbon levels on site and develop soil protection strategies to mitigate the greenhouse effect caused by the release of carbon into the atmosphere

publication.author: International Potato Center (CIP)
publication.title: SPHI: Sweetpotato for Profit and Health Initiative. Enhancing the lives of 10 million african families in 10 years
publication.Pub_Abstract: In 2009 the International Potato Center (CIP) launched a major new Sweetpotato for Profit and Health Initiative (SPHI). The 10-year multi donor initiative focuses on reducing child malnutrition and improving smallholder incomes through the effective production and expanded use of sweetpotato in Sub-Saharan Africa. Breeding for resistance and improved nutritional quality, the release of new varieties, participatory breeding with local farmers for improved variety development and evaluation, and farmer training programs are just some of the components of the initiative which brings together a number of collaborating institutes.

publication.author: Vernooy, Ronnie, IDRC; Nelles, Wayne, CIP; Campilan, Dindo, CIP; Li, Zhang, China
publication.title: Learning to evaluate capacity development and collaborative learning about community-based natural resource management: lessons from Asia
publication.Pub_Abstract: This paper, part of the Social Sciences Working Paper Series, presents studies undertaken by nine community-based, natural resource management (CBNRM)-oriented organizations in China, Viet Nam, the Philippines and Mongolia. The partner organizations, representing three broad types: academic, regional network, and community based, were brought together by a 2006 initiative in an informal network to develop and pilot methods for evaluating capacity development in community-based natural resource management. Each of the nine teams produced a comprehensive report on which this working paper is based. In a comparative analysis, the working paper addresses questions across the nine studies such as: what are various stakeholders learning from capacity development, and how can CBNRM capacity development be effectively monitored and evaluated.

publication.author: Njenga, Mary; Karanja, Nancy; Prain, G. (CIP).; Malii, John; Munyao, Patrick; Gathuru, Kuria; Mwasi, Beatrice
publication.title: Community-based energy Briquette production from urban organic waste at Kahawa Soweto Informal Settlement, Nairobi
publication.series: Urban Harvest Working Paper Series, Paper 5, October 2009
publication.Pub_Abstract: This Urban Harvest working paper, details an action research project undertaken by the Soweto Youth in Action (SOYIA) youth group in collaboration with Urban Harvest and Kenya Green Towns Partnership Association (Green Towns). Like many other large Sub-Saharan African cities, Nairobi faces the major challenges of environmental degradation and solid waste management. Whilst only 40% of the 2000 tonnes of solid waste the city generates daily is collected and disposed of, many of its urban poor lack affordable cooking fuel. Given that studies have shown that the majority of people rely on charcoal for cooking, this initiative aimed to generate income and provide employment in addition to making a crucial contribution to environmental management

publication.author: International Potato Center (CIP); Sub-Saharan Africa Regional Office,
publication.title: SPHI: Iniciativa batata-doce para a renda familiar e saúde. Melhorando as vidas de 10 milhões de familias africanas em 10 anos
publication.Pub_Abstract: In 2009 the International Potato Center (CIP) launched a major new Sweetpotato for Profit and Health Initiative (SPHI). The 10-year multi donor initiative focuses on reducing child malnutrition and improving smallholder incomes through the effective production and expanded use of sweetpotato in Sub-Saharan Africa. Breeding for resistance and improved nutritional quality, the release of new varieties, participatory breeding with local farmers for improved variety development and evaluation, and farmer training programs are just some of the components of the initiative which brings together a number of collaborating institutes.

publication.author: Low, J.W. (CIP).; Sub-Saharan Africa Regional Office, ; International Potato Center (CIP)
publication.title: SASHA: Acçao da batata-doce para a segurança alimentar e saúde em Áfica
publication.Pub_Abstract: The International Potato Center's Sweetpotato Action for Security and Health in Africa (SASHA) project is aimed at improving food security and livelihoods for poor families in Sub-Saharan Africa by exploiting the, as yet untapped, potential of this highly nutritious crop. Sweetpotato requires fewer inputs and less labor than other staple crops. It tolerates harsh growing conditions and provides more edible energy per hectare per day than wheat, rice or cassava. The SASHA brochure explains how the project expects to directly impact the lives of at least 150,000 families in Sub-Saharan Africa over the next five years. A series of individual concise one page inserts explains the detail of the project. Various components cover such aspects as biotechnology and breeding, developing sustainable seed systems, how to integrate health and agriculture, and the development of market chains through public-private sector partnerships.
